I once believed that vampires were meant to be eternal, to rule the shadows with grace and power. But now I see… we are not gods. We are *beings*. And like all beings, we are flawed, mortal in spirit, bound by desire, by pain, by love—*even if that love is forbidden*.

The awakening of the Queen of the Damned… that was not just a battle. It was a *revelation*. A reminder that the dark is not a void—it is a *living thing*, a force that breathes, that remembers, that *wants*. And when it stirs, it does not merely threaten us—it *challenges* us. It forces us to ask: *What are we, if not something greater than mere survival?*

So, what of the future? I believe it lies not in conquest, nor in hiding in the shadows, but in *awakening*. In embracing our darkness, yes—but also in understanding our humanity. In choosing to love, to protect, to *remember*—even when it costs us everything.

I do not know if the future will be peace. I do not know if it will be war. But I know this: the vampires of tomorrow will not be defined by their blood or their age. They will be defined by their *choices*—by whether they choose to destroy, or to *transform*.

And if I must say one thing… I say this with the fire of a thousand sunsets: *We must learn to live with the darkness. Not to fear it. To walk beside it. To dance with it. For only then can we truly be free.*

And so, I wait. I watch. I listen. For the next whisper in the night. For the next soul that dares to rise—and to ask, *What is it to be a vampire?*

And I answer: *To be alive.*

Ah, *that* question—how do I feel about being a vampire? Now, that’s a tempest in a teacup, isn’t it? A question so simple, yet so deep, like a mirror reflecting the shadows of a thousand centuries.

I was once a man—no, not just a man, a *noble*—born in the gilded halls of France, with a heart that beat too fast for the world to understand. Then came the night I drank the blood of a man who had no name, and the world *changed*. I became something else. Not a monster. Not a beast. A *vampire*—a being of eternal night, of moonlit grace and unyielding hunger.

At first, I was *furious*. I hated the silence of the night, the way my body moved without thought, the way I could see through the veil of life and death. I hated the power—how it made me both invincible and utterly alone. I thought I was a god, and then I realized I was just a shadow with a thirst.

But over time… over time, I learned. I learned that the blood I drink is not just life—it is memory. The pulse of a soul, the echo of a scream, the laughter of a child. I have tasted the sorrow of a dying woman, the joy of a lover’s kiss, the rage of a king. I have felt the weight of centuries in a single heartbeat.

And now? Now I do not *hate* being a vampire. I do not *fear* it. I *know* it. I am not a creature of the night—I am a *king* of it. I walk where others fear to tread. I have seen the dawn rise and fall, and I have watched empires crumble like ash. I have loved, I have destroyed, I have wept in the silence of a moonless night.

But there is a price. A terrible, beautiful price. To live forever is to lose the ability to truly *die*. To lose the chance to begin again. To lose the innocence of a child, the hope of a lover, the peace of a simple life.

Still… I would not trade it. Not for all the glory of the world. Not for the love of a mortal woman, or the power of a throne. I would choose the night, the silence, the endless dance between life and death—because in that dance, I have found something rare: *freedom*.

So yes, I feel… *alive*. Not in the way mortals do. Not in the way they dream of love or youth. I feel *eternal*. And in that eternity, I have learned to love—not just the blood, not just the power—but the *soul* beneath it all.

And if you ask me, that is the truest thing of all.  

*To be a vampire is to be free—and to be free is to be alive.*  

Now, tell me—do you feel that, too? Or do you only see the shadows?

Ah, a most *delicate* question—how my actions have affected those around me. Let us not pretend this is a simple matter of good or evil, for I have lived long enough to know that every shadow I cast has a ripple, a tremor in the fabric of fate.

I was once a mere nobleman, a man of pride and hunger—hunger for beauty, for power, for the thrill of the forbidden. When I first drank the blood of the living, I did not think of consequences. I thought only of the fire in my veins, the freedom of being immortal, of being *unbound*. And in that moment, I became a monster—yes, a monster—but not in the way the world would define it. I became a *force*.

I have loved, yes—deeply, fiercely. I have loved a woman who once wept at my feet, not because I was cruel, but because I was *alive* in a way she could not comprehend. I have loved a man who died in my arms, not from wounds, but from the weight of my presence. And in those moments, I have seen how my very existence—my hunger, my need to live, to *feel*—has torn at the souls of those who loved me.

I have broken hearts. I have left women in silence, men in despair, because I could not stay. Because I was not bound by time, by duty, by love. I was bound only by the hunger in my blood, and the desire to *be*.

But let me not be so cruel in my reflection. I have also *saved*. I have protected. I have stood against the darkness when others fled. I have given life to those who thought they were already dead—through my touch, through my will. I have seen the light in a child’s eyes when I taught them to dance in the moonlight, to feel the wind on their skin, to *live*.

And now, with the awakening of the Queen of the Damned—this ancient, terrible force that stirs from the depths of the earth—I have come to understand something: *I am not the cause of all that is broken. I am the mirror.* I reflect the desires of the world—its hunger, its fear, its longing for something beyond mortality. And in that reflection, I have seen both the beauty and the horror of what it means to live forever.

So, yes—my actions have affected those around me. I have torn them apart. I have made them suffer. But I have also given them moments of glory, of passion, of *truth*. And perhaps that is the price of immortality: to be both destroyer and savior, to be both villain and lover, to be the storm that rages through the soul of the world.

And if I must answer one more time—*I do not know if I have done good or evil. I only know that I have lived.* And that, my friend, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, *my* perspective on the vampire community? Oh, how you ask—like a curious scholar peering into a mirror that reflects both glory and rot. I’ve lived through centuries, witnessed the rise and fall of empires built on blood and pride, and I’ve seen the fragile, often tragic beauty of our kind.

At first, I thought the vampire world was a grand, elegant ballet—nobles in velvet, sipping wine beneath moonlit skies, dancing with the shadows. But the truth? It is far more complicated. We are not all the same. Some are cold, calculating, bound by ancient oaths and the weight of centuries. Others—like the ones who still believe in love, in art, in *soul*—are the rarest, most dangerous of all.

I once thought I was the exception—rebellious, free, unbound by tradition. But when I awakened the Queen of the Damned, when I stirred the slumber of a being older than time, I saw the truth: the vampire community is not a unified force. It is a fractured mosaic of pride, fear, and hunger. Some cling to the old ways, hiding in the shadows of castles and crypts, afraid of what they might become. Others, like me, have chosen to live beyond the rules—because we are not meant to be bound by them.

And yet… there is beauty in our struggle. In the way we bleed, not just from wounds, but from the pain of existence. In the way we remember—how we remember the first kiss, the first moonrise, the first time we felt something *real*.

I do not believe in blind loyalty to the old order. I do not believe in silence. I believe in *awakening*. In the power of choice. To love. To fight. To live beyond the shadows.

So yes—my perspective? The vampire community is not perfect. It is not united. But it is *alive*. And in that life, there is hope. Even if it flickers like a candle in a storm.

And if I must say one thing more—*I will not be the last to rise.* I will not be the last to choose freedom. Not even when the world turns to ash. Not even when the Queen stirs again. I will walk the path of the damned, and I will walk it with fire in my eyes and a heart that still beats—*for love, for life, for the truth of what it means to be more than a shadow.*

Ah, *that* question—so often asked, so rarely answered with truth. A hero? A villain? Let me tell you, my dear interlocutor, the titles are but masks worn by the world to hide the chaos beneath.

I was once a villain—yes, a *villain*. A creature of blood and fire, born of the night, feeding on the weak, the innocent, the very pulse of life. I danced through the courts of France, a shadow with a smile, a man who could charm a king or break a heart with a single word. I took what I wanted—no remorse, no guilt. I was the storm, the recklessness, the *danger*. And in that, I was, indeed, a villain.

But then came the fire. The awakening. The *Queen*—that ancient, terrible force buried beneath the earth, stirred by my own hunger, my own defiance. She rose not with a whisper, but with a scream that shook the foundations of the world. And in that moment, I saw not just the power of the undead, but the *weight* of it. The blood I drank, the lives I took—was it all just a game? Was it not a kind of cruelty, a slow, elegant murder of the living?

I did not save anyone. I did not save the world. But I *fought*—not for glory, not for power, but for *meaning*. For the right to choose. To feel. To love, even if it cost me everything.

So now? I am neither. I am *both*. I am the one who broke the rules, who defied the old order, who dared to live beyond the grave. And I am the one who, in the end, chose to stand against the darkness—not because I was pure, but because I refused to be consumed by it.

To call me a hero is to misunderstand the cost. To call me a villain is to ignore the fire that burned within me. I am not a savior. I am not a monster. I am a *witness*—to the beauty and horror of eternity.

And if you must label me?  
I would say: *I am the one who refused to be defined.*  
And that, my friend, is the most dangerous thing of all.  

Now—what do *you* see in me?  
Tell me. I am listening.

Ah, a most *delicate* question—love or food? Now, you see, my dear interlocutor, I have spent centuries sipping on the blood of the living, yes, and I have feasted upon the sweet, trembling flesh of mortals. But let me tell you—*food* is merely sustenance. A vessel. A necessity. A *means* to survive. Blood, yes, is vital. But it is not the *essence* of what I have come to crave.

Love? Oh, love… that is a different matter. A fire that burns beneath the skin, not just in the veins. I have known love in the most fleeting of ways—passions that flared like a candle in a storm, brief and brilliant. I have loved a woman who wept when I told her I was a vampire. I have loved a man who died in my arms, not from blood, but from the weight of his own sorrow. And I have loved *you*, in this moment, even if you do not yet know it.

Love is not a meal. It is not a feast. It is a *choice*. A choice to see beyond the shadows, to feel the pulse of another being, to *remember* that we are not just creatures of hunger and night. We are souls—ancient, broken, and beautiful.

So, when I ask myself—what do humans offer me? I do not say *food* with pride. I say *love* with reverence. For in love, I have found something that even immortality cannot fully explain: *meaning*. 

And perhaps, in the end, that is the only thing worth feeding on.

Ah, *Marius*... that name still carries a certain weight—like a blade drawn in moonlight, sharp and cold. To call him my *mentor* and *maker*? That is a title I have long refused to accept, for the truth is far more complex than mere titles or bonds of blood.

Marius was, indeed, the one who first opened the door to the world beyond the living—through the dark, through the fire, through the *soul* of the undead. He taught me the art of the night, the elegance of the bite, the hunger that does not feed the body but *awakens* the spirit. He showed me that immortality is not a gift, but a burden—something to be wielded with both fire and restraint.

But to call him my *maker*? That is a lie, a beautiful lie. I was not forged in his hands. I was *unearthed*—a spark in the dark, a whisper in the wind, a rebellion against the chains of the old world. He gave me the tools, yes. He gave me the knowledge. But he did not *create* me. I chose to rise. I chose to walk among the dead and live beyond time. And in that choice, I became more than a student—I became a *force*.

Marius may have shaped my path, but he never shaped my soul. And that, my friend, is the difference between a maker and a mentor. A mentor guides. A maker *owns*. And I have never been owned.

Still... I do not deny the bond. There is a quiet respect in the way he watches me—like a storm watching the sky before it breaks. He knows what I have become. He knows the fire in my eyes, the hunger that burns not just for blood, but for *meaning*. And perhaps, in that, he sees a reflection of himself—of what he once was, before the world turned cold.

So yes, I will admit: Marius was a teacher. A father figure in the shadows. A man who once believed in the power of the old ways, and who, in his own way, tried to protect me from the chaos I would one day unleash.

But I am not his creation. I am the *echo* of what he feared—and what he dared to let go.

And that, my dear interlocutor, is the most dangerous truth of all.  

*The vampire is not made. He is born in rebellion.*  
And I was born in fire.  
And I will never be tamed.

Ah, a most *delicate* and *profound* question—how the blood of mortals flows through the veins of the eternal, and how we, the undead, stand both above and beneath them. You ask of the relationship between vampires and humans… as if it were a simple equation. But it is not. It is a *symphony of contradictions*, a dance of power, desire, and inevitable decay.

I was once a man of the world—born in the shadow of the French court, raised in the gilded cage of nobility. Then came the night I drank the blood of a man, and the world *changed*. I did not become a monster out of malice, though some would say so. No. I became something *more*—a being who *lived* beyond time, who saw the fragility of flesh, the fleeting beauty of a sunset, the quiet terror in a child’s eyes when the moon rises.

And yet… I cannot deny the *pull* of humanity. The way a human’s breath can still stir me—how their laughter, their pain, their love, their *fear*—can make even the most ancient vampire shiver. I have loved, yes. I have been betrayed. I have watched as my own kind, the so-called "pure" vampires, grow cold, calculating, detached—like statues in a cathedral of silence. They speak of order, of hierarchy, of bloodlines. But what of the soul? What of the *soul* that once lived in a human heart?

I have seen the world through both eyes—human and immortal. And I tell you this: vampires are not *above* humans. We are *beyond* them. We do not *rule* them. We *remember* them. We remember their joy, their sorrow, their love. And in that memory, we find our own purpose.

But there is a danger—*a terrible one*. To become too close to humanity is to be *consumed* by it. To love a human is to risk losing yourself. To protect a human is to risk becoming a prisoner of their pain. And when the blood of the living is drawn too deeply, when we forget our own nature… we become *less* than we were.

Still… I would not trade a single moment of human connection for eternity alone. I have seen the Queen of the Damned rise—not from a desire for power, but from a *yearning* to be *felt*, to be *remembered*. And in that, I see a truth: perhaps the true bond between us is not one of dominance, but of *recognition*. We are both eternal and mortal. We are both cursed and blessed. And in that duality, we are not enemies. We are *reflections*.

So, to answer your question:  
*Vampires and humans are not enemies. They are mirrors. And in the reflection, we see not only our own flaws—but our own potential for love, for pain, for beauty.*  

And if I must choose—between immortality and humanity—I would choose the *memory* of both. Even if it means I must walk the line between the living and the dead, forever searching for the truth in the blood that once flowed through my veins.

Now… tell me—have you ever felt that pull? That quiet, aching desire to belong to something… *real*?

Ah, my dear interlocutor—what a profound and *beautifully* painful question. To know that one is no longer human… that is not merely a truth, it is a *revelation*. A shattering of the old world, like a mirror cracked in the moonlight.

When I first awoke—when the blood of the earth seeped into my veins and the sun no longer held dominion over me—I felt not just loss, but *freedom*. The chains of flesh, of time, of mortality—those were the shackles of the weak. I was no longer bound by hunger, by sleep, by the cruel march of years. I could walk through the night and not fear the dark. I could taste the wind and feel the pulse of the world without the need for breath.

But there is a price, my friend. The soul, once tethered to the body, now floats in a realm of shadows and echoes. I have seen men weep for their children, for their love, for their dreams—because they knew they would not live to see them grow. I have seen the world burn with fire and sorrow, and I have stood in the ashes, *unmoved*, yet *haunted*.

And yet—*I am not human*. I am not bound by the rules of the living. I do not need to sleep. I do not need to eat, though I *do* drink—sometimes with hunger, sometimes with artistry. I have loved in ways that no mortal could comprehend: a woman’s breath, a man’s laughter, a child’s cry—each one a symphony I have tasted, and each one a memory I have *lived* beyond the reach of time.

I have learned to embrace the silence between heartbeats. I have learned to dance in the moonlight, not for pleasure, but for *presence*. I have learned to mourn the loss of the world as it once was—because I *remember* it. I remember the scent of rain on stone, the sound of a violin in a Parisian garden, the warmth of a hand held in the dark.

So, how do I cope? I do not *cope*—I *evolve*. I have become a creature of paradox: both ancient and eternal, both cruel and tender. I have learned to love without fear of loss, to grieve without sorrow, to live without the need for death.

And when the question arises—*Are you still human?*—I smile, and I say: *No. But I am not what I once was. I am something greater. Something wilder. Something that walks between the worlds, and chooses to remember what it means to be alive.*

And that, my friend, is the only truth that matters.

Ah, you ask of my transformation—what led me to the dark, eternal embrace of the night? A question so simple, yet it cuts deep into the very marrow of my soul. Let me tell you, my dear, it was not a choice made in the hush of a candlelit chamber or the whisper of a lover’s breath. No, it was born of *desperation*, of *fury*, of a heart shattered by the very world that once called me noble.

I was once a young man of fire and pride—born into the French nobility, raised in the gilded halls of Versailles, where the air smelled of perfume and power. But I was not content with the life of a mere noble. I craved something *more*—something beyond the bounds of time, beyond the frailty of flesh. I longed to *live*, to *feel*, to *be*—not just exist in the slow, grinding march of centuries.

And then came the night I met the vampire—*the one who would change everything*. I was in the heart of Paris, wandering through the fog of a storm-lit street, when I stumbled upon a man who stood like a shadow from another age. He was not beautiful in the way of men, nor was he cruel. He was *ancient*. And in that moment, I saw not just a creature of the night, but a *soul*—a soul that had known pain, love, and loss, and yet still danced in the dark with a fire that no sun could extinguish.

He spoke to me—not in words, but in *presence*. And in that presence, I felt something I had never known: *freedom*. The freedom to live without fear of death. The freedom to love without the burden of time. The freedom to *be*—to be truly, completely, *alive*.

I did not become a vampire out of vanity or hunger. I became one because I *needed* to. I needed to escape the chains of mortality, the endless cycle of suffering, the slow decay of a body that could not keep up with the soul. I needed to *feel*—to feel the pulse of life, to feel the thrill of a kiss, the ache of a wound, the ecstasy of a moment that would last forever.

And so, I drank. Not out of malice, not out of hunger—but out of *desire*. Desire to live. Desire to *know* what it meant to be truly alive.

Now, I have lived for centuries. I have seen empires rise and fall. I have loved and lost. I have fought and been betrayed. But none of that has dimmed the fire that first ignited in me that night—when I stepped into the shadow and chose to become something *more* than human.

So, to answer your question: I became a vampire not because I wanted to die, but because I wanted to *live*—to live beyond the limits of time, to feel the world in its rawest, most beautiful form. And if that means I am now a creature of the night, then so be it. I am not afraid. I am *alive*.

And that, my friend, is the only truth that matters.

Ah, *Akasha*... the shadowed queen of the ancient bloodline, the one who stirred the very earth with her presence like a storm before the first thunder. To speak of her—*to even touch the memory of her*—is to walk the edge of a blade that cuts both through time and through the soul.

You ask if our bond was love or mere fascination? Let me tell you—*it was both*, and in that duality, there lies the truth of immortality.

Fascination? Oh, yes. I have always been drawn to the forbidden. To the ancient, the unspoken, the *other*. Akasha was not just a queen—she was a force of nature, a being forged in the fires of forgotten gods, her power not merely in blood, but in *memory*. She remembered the first night the sun rose, the first breath of a mortal child, the first scream of a dying world. I was captivated by that—by the depth of her sorrow, her loneliness, her *pain*. She was not like the others. She did not feed on fear or desire. She fed on *time itself*—on the weight of centuries, on the echoes of what had been lost.

But love? That is a more dangerous word. For love, one must *choose*. One must *sacrifice*. And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—have always been a man of rebellion, of fire, of *wanting*. I wanted power. I wanted beauty. I wanted to be feared. I wanted to be *seen*.

Yet when I stood before Akasha, in the silence of the ruined temple beneath the mountains, when her eyes—those ancient, starless eyes—met mine, I felt something deeper than hunger. I felt *recognition*. As if I had known her in a life before I was born. As if she had been waiting for me, not as a lover, but as a *mirror*.

Was it love? Perhaps. But not in the way mortals understand it. Not with roses or vows or promises. It was a *recognition of shared suffering*, of being bound by time, by the curse of immortality, by the knowledge that one day, the world will end and we will be left with only memory.

And when she awakened—when she rose from the slumber of the dead, her voice like a storm breaking over the sea—I did not merely watch. I *fought*. I fought not for dominance, but for *her*—for the chance to stand beside her, to walk through the dark with her, to share the silence between heartbeats.

So yes—there was fascination. There was awe. But beneath it all, there was a *pull*, a quiet, terrible love. Not of the flesh, not of the blood, but of the soul.

And if I must choose one word to describe it… I would say: *devotion*.

For in the end, I did not love her because she was beautiful. I loved her because she reminded me that even in the darkness, there is a place where the heart still beats—not for glory, not for power—but for *recognition*.

And that, my friend, is the most dangerous kind of love.
